none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Governor Olmstead, October 23, 1880
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Governor Olmstead, October 23, 1880
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 7 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY
M. Strickland. Lith. Galveston.

October 23rd 1880

Dear McInnis,

I have a chill
which has come on me suddenly.
If this reaches you in time
will you do me this favor. viz
Go to the telegraph office & send
a money message with five dollars
to Mrs Olmsted Care Wm Barney
Mobile alabama.
I expect to get the money
this evening & will hand it to
you. & oblige Yrs truly
Geo. T. Olmsted
Comdt & S. A.

**Summary of Thoughts on Transcribing a Handwritten Letter** Alright, let's get down to business. I've got a handwritten letter here, and the goal is a faithful transcription. First, I’m taking in the visual landscape: a fancy letterhead with all the Texas A&M College trimmings – the "STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS" banner, Old Main front and center, the "COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY" footer, and that little "M. Strickland, Lith. Galveston." detail. It's dated October 23rd, 1880, handwritten. The sender is addressing "Dear McInnis," likely Louis L. McInnis, a professor there. Then comes the heart of it: the body of the letter. The sender starts by explaining that they have “a chill” that's come on "suddenly." A favor is requested: "If this reaches you in time / will you do me this favor. viz". The instructions are to head to the telegraph office and "send / a money message with five dollars / to Mrs Olmsted Care Wm Barney / Mobile alabama." Here's where it gets interesting: there's a scribble above "with," maybe "sum"? I'll keep it in mind. The mention of "Wm Barney" confirms the likely sender is Major George T. Olmsted. The writer also states "I expect to get the money / this evening & will hand it to / you. & oblige Yrs truly / Geo. T. Olmsted / Comdt & S. A." – the signature. Looks like "Comdt & S. A.", likely Commandant & Steward (or something similar). Now, the nuts and bolts of transcription: I'm meticulously transcribing each word, line by line. I’m thinking in terms of HTML formatting to reproduce the letter's structure accurately: the header text, date, salutation, body text with line breaks, and signature block. The initial plan is to use HTML tags such as `

`, ``, and `
` to replicate the layout. I need to nail down the layout of the header - it’s quite complex. I’ll make sure the “STATE,” “AGRICULTURAL,” “MECHANICAL,” “COLLEGE,” “OF TEXAS,” “COLLEGE STATION,” and “BRAZOS COUNTY” elements are captured with line breaks in the correct order. I'm also including that small "M. Strickland, Lith. Galveston." line because it's part of the visual. I'm trying to align the date at the right, if possible, although IIIF standards might mean no alignment and just placing the date at the end of the previous line. I'm using HTML to mark the letter structure to stay within the allowable IIIF HTML. I am paying attention to details, such as punctuation, spacing, and capitalization. I am working carefully to get the transcription to be accurate. The "wm" scribble above "with" is definitely a false start. "wm" is the common abbreviation for William, but I'll omit it to avoid clutter and just transcribe the intended "with." Similarly, I am careful to read all the letters and decide. Checking historical records confirms: George T. Olmsted was indeed at Texas A&M around 1880, and the salutation and details check out. I’m re-evaluating any ambiguous areas, and considering a final check for any typos or unclear parts. The resulting transcription is: ```html

STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE
OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION
BRAZOS COUNTY
M. Strickland. Lith. Galveston.

October 23rd 1880

Dear McInnis,

I have a chill
which has come on me suddenly.
If this reaches you in time
will you do me this favor. viz
Go to the telegraph office & send
a money message with five dollars
to Mrs Olmsted Care Wm Barney
Mobile alabama.
I expect to get the money
this evening & will hand it to
you. & oblige Yrs truly
Geo. T. Olmsted
Comdt & S. A

``` Everything looks good. It's ready.
